He has had one exciting life, I do have to say,

I always read things about the things that make

57.text: >>  I teach, and in fact, I had a lecture today,.

I've told students, and I've told writers that work 
for me,

68.text:
if you think you're telling the truth you're

know the truth.

74.text:
We know what we're told, we know what we 
hear, we know what we see, we know what 
we've read,

79.text:
we know everything coming into us, information-
wise,  but we only relay what we know.

If it turns out to be the truth, great.  Often, as we

We can come up with all kinds of examples of

>> That's one great, glaring example.  We can

132.text:
then, the reader, the viewer, the audience, has 
the information that they can make a decision 
on,

and then we'll see how it plays out,and what

Does editorial thinking sneak into the news

154.text:
>> You mean, bias?  It's there.  It's not sneaking

Everyone has biases. Everyone. You cannot be

How you function, how you are judged, how you

with your biases,

and how you the filter out the ones that aren't

favorable.

In teaching and managing writers, David Broder 
said it best: "Good journalists are skeptical of 
their sources and of their own biases."

And so, in class and management, I always try 
to say, "Be aware of yourself.  Listen to 
yourself."

201.text:
Know yourself, what you like and don't like. 
When you're writing something. or reporting 
something,

206.text:
a little bell goes off, and says "I like that", or

to figure out

what you might be leaking into, or pouring into a

>> We've done a lot interesting things,but one of

You said it was for news, information and

we talking about?

256.text:
>> You have to understand what sort of radio 
station it was, at first.  This was a US Army 
created radio station.

262.text:
It basically was a "psyop" - Psychological 
Operations - radio station.

267.text:
It was created to influence the Southern 
Afghanistan population to bring issues to them 
that the army and the coalition

274.text:
felt were not being brought by the regular media. 
If you would call that "propaganda", fine.  But, 
that's a very loaded word in American English.

283.text: But, yeah, it was propaganda in a way.

286.text:
>> I want to go back, and pull out one or two 
words: a "psychological operation". OK, I think 
that's important.

294.text:
>> It is designed to encourage Afghans to think 
a certain way about the coalition and about the 
government.

305.text:
What they did - this was at Kandahar Airfield -  
iwas was an FM station, 88.5, Radio Together, 
Radio Yowali.

313.text:
They put together this station, and the army, the 
Tenth Mountain Division, was in charge of that 
region at the time.

318.text:
They had no idea what to do with it, once the 
thing was technically built.  So they hides a 
comany, and the company hired me.

324.text:
I had a staff of about twenty-five Afghan 
journalists and studio technicians.  I had two 
other Americans helping me, managing it.

333.text:
>> In Pashto, so we had everything translated.  
The Afghan Journalists were told - and they 
knew who they were working for -

342.text:
they're still there - but they said, "You've got to 
have credibility.

346.text:
In every Psychological Operation manual, one of 
the first things it will say is,  "To have any kind 
of effect, it has to have credibility."

353.text:
So we said, "You just do the news that you 
think you ought to do.

357.text:
You do the stories you want to do. We had 
reporters in the field - one of them was a 
woman.  Brilliant, very courageous.

362.text:
We talked about the provincial government not 
getting the roads paved.

367.text:
We talked about unemployment.  We talked 
about the bad security situation.

370.text:
The Tenth Mountain Division, to their eternal 
credit, was the only military until I ever worked 
with, in an immediate capacity,

377.text:
that said, "OK, we've got to take this.  We don't 
like it, but for the sake of credibility, we have to 
do this."

384.text:
So, they were very light-handed, in how the 
news, information, interviews and cultural 
programming was done, on the station.

391.text: >> So, you had a rather free hand?

392.text:
>> Pretty much of a free hand, yes.  When 
there was something really sensitive, we'd tell 
them about it.

398.text:
There was not one time when the Tenth 
Mountain Division said "you can't run that".

403.text:
They would prepare a response, and we'd have 
the response as well. So, they always had the 
first or last word, as it was their radio station.

We had call-ins,  SMS texting to which they 
could subscribe to get our headlies,.  We played 
nothing but local music.

419.text:
>> Did you get some interesting texts, and call-
ins?

421.text:
>> Oh, absolutely. We had a pretty good feel for 
what people were thinking about certain issues.

426.text: >> That must have been of some importance?

429.text:
>> That's the point. That's why they liked it so 
much.

434.text: >> You're very good.  You get it!

436.text:
The commanding general of Regional Command 
South called it the most effective psychological 
operation enterprise of the entire Afghan war.

447.text:
I think that was a little over-the-top. But, they 
were very happy with the response they were 
getting.

452.text:
With the SMS texting, when a bombing 
happened, or something happening in Kandahar 
City,

458.text:
we would send out a text, saying what's 
happened, not as much a public service, as 
"stay away from that area". They love that.

465.text:
We learned attitudes about the Americans, the 
coalition, the government, and the Taliban.  All of 
these we learned from call-ins we got, every day.

>> I think that's fascinating.  Before you did it in

>> It was a lot different.  In the late summer of

They wanted to create a PBS, NPR-style public

They brought me and a couple of folks that I

>> What you did was, and I must quote you,   
"You insisted that the wire report,  the news 
agency pictures of the carnage,

and the fact that we had sent a correspondent to

We said, "We'll do the journalism, here,

If the occupied, in effect, are to believe what

We started doing newscasts in the evening, live

We started getting some positive feedback.

Defense Department just couldn't let go.

They had to have control. They wanted to shape 
the message, and all the aspects of the media.

576.text:
>> That doesn't work, because the people who 
are listening don't have the trust in the credibility 
of what's going out?

582.text:
>> They knew who was putting it out. Of course, 
you're absolutely right.

585.text:
>> What I've read, and I rather like the article on 
this subject, and it said that language was a 
problem, too,

591.text: because you didn't have anybody that spoke...

594.text:
>> They were all Iraqis.  The "Iraqi Media 
Network".  That three-entity system ...

601.text:
>> But, the people who were running that, didn't 
speak..

604.text:
>> Our supervisors, the folks at CPA, did not.
They were working through translators, and that 
wasn't very good.

612.text:
They didn't understand what Iraqis needed, at 
that point.

So, the project, the effort lasted a year, with the 
company I worked for, then another company 
came in with a contract.

When the CPA left Iraq in June 2004,they

government of the time, the governing council,

and it has now become simply a government

>> One of the interesting problems - I just think 
this is fascinating -

when they first started the Iraqi Media Network,

The translating was kind of a problem, and 
where he was, was also a problem,

655.text:
because they moved into the palace where 
Saddam Hussein had been, and the message 
that sent was not good.

>> Five months later, that totally changed 
around.  He asked us to do an interview program 
with him.  This was in December, 2003.

We put it in a cafe in the Rashid hotel. We 
picked the two Iraqi journalists who would

The CPA had no voice in who was going to 
interview Bremer.

683.text:
It was unrehearsed.  He didn't know what he

He would come to the cafe, he would sit down, it

>> He tried. Yes.  Honorable, definitely.  I some

>> But, he recognized that was how he was

>> Is it easy to evaluate these two attempts in

719.text:
>> Well, in Iraq, yeah, that was 10 years ago, 
now.

723.text:
It became what everyone did not want it to

>> Afghanistan is a different situation, because

Immediately after the Afghan war was over, the

So, with Radio Yowali, the station we created, it

The idea is, at some point, cranes and truck will

with either a private Afghan media mogul, a

>> I love it. It's interesting, because there are so

I found the funniest quote: Lyndon Johnson said,

the water across the Potomac River,

the headline that afternoon would read 'The

This is a good segue into the many, many ways

The problem isn't that there's too much 
information, because there never can be too 
much information.

823.text:
But a lot of people are throwing up their hands,

know where to look.  I don't have time for this."

So, they tend to gravitate toward the things that

842.text:
>> It's a cafeteria, but there always going for the

The problem there is that perceptions and ideas

The way I put it is: people love to be 
enlightened,  but they don't like to be 
challenged.

860.text:
They don't mind learning new stull, as long as it

are.

1094.text: >> Right now, that's a pretty hot topic.  There are a lot of lawsuits popping up. There are a lot of complaints been filed.

1103.text: It's something that's bothered me for a long time. We're talking about for-profit companies.  They're the only ones that apply, in this case.

1112.text: Governments and non-profits are allowed to have internships that are not paid, but for-profit companies, as I understood the law,

1120.text: and I've read it, is that they can have interns, as long as the interns don't directly contribute to the product of the company.

1126.text: Well, there are interns out there, who are getting nothing, who are doing work of what normally would be a paid employee.

1138.text: They are taking the spots of, in many cases, of someone who needs a job.

1152.text: >> Exactly.  It's a limiter, in some respects, on who can get into the business.  I think it's a bad practice.

1158.text: I understand why they do it.  I understand the temptation. I've had to manage budgets.

1163.text: But, at the same time, I just think, give them credit, give them a stipend, pay for a little apartment, or something.

1242.text: This is a way of protesting what I'm sure they consider to be the biased, unfair, anti-Assad, anti-Syrian, anti-Arab coverage they're getting

1296.text: My mother's German, my father's American, they met right after World War Two in Germany, and got married, there.

1302.text: The oral histories of my mother's family surviving the post-war period,

1309.text: a lot of the anecdotes, I did some research, and added some things in.  I also discussed in a broader sense how we did that occupation right.

1318.text: We don't seem to know how to do occupations anymore.

1321.text: >> We shouldn't be doing any, perhaps.

1324.text: But, if we do an occupation, we at least ought to be able to do it right.We did it right in Germany, but we haven't done it well, since.

1331.text: So, I pulled all these things together into a novel.  There are some family skeletons I brought out of the closet for the story's sake,

1339.text: and there are a lot of things I made up.  I was just one of those things I really felt like writing. It took me a while to write it, but it's published.

1353.text: But, it's there. It's gotten some traction, but, generally, it's a story that I felt needed to be told, so I told it.

1359.text: >> It's called, "The Golden Times", by Ted Iliff.  I think, underneath your family, and all that, you talked about, really, a shattered nation.

1372.text: And, you talked about the cities and the national soul, that was scarred, has gotten somewhat less scarred, but it is scarred, forever.

1380.text: And, what happens, out of the debris, sometimes, the regime is salvaged.

1387.text: >> Yes.  The amazing thing about Germany is that you always need to be careful,

1391.text: because Germany has the collective guilt of the Holocaust, and it will never go away. They concede and admit it will never go away.

1400.text: So, whenever you're talking about Germany in a historical context,  that factor of German history is always there.

1406.text: Beyond that, here was a whole generation - my mother was one of that generation - late teens early twenties.

1412.text: They had grown up in the Hitler system.  During their most important teen years, they had a war.

1416.text: Some of them fought in it, but all of them had been scarred by it.  The War end, and their entire courty and society had been shattered.

1423.text: They stand up, and they say, "OK, that sucked.  That was terrible."

1432.text: Then, they say, "All right. Now we know what to do", and they get on with it.

1529.text: >> The most interesting place I've ever worked?    It had to be Afghanistan, because I worked there so long, I really got to know it, pretty well.

1541.text: >> Well, the Afghans - this is from our call-ins, we actually asked this, several times -

1576.text: >> Well, I have to say that it has been such a pleasure talking to you, today.

1581.text: >> And, I would say to you, don't we have interesting neighbors?
